# str_trim

<center>
![](images/stringr_str_trim.png){style="width:200px"}
</center>

The function `stringr::str_trim()` removes white spaces.

White spaces are:

- Space: ` `
- Tab: `\t`
- Newline: `\n`

[Tidyverse reference page](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/reference/str_trim.html)

## String vector

Prior to using the function create a vector with various different strings.

```{r}
#Create vector of strings
vec <- c("   Spaces to the left of me", 
        "Newlines to the right\n\n",
        "Here I am,", 
        "\t\tStuck in the middle of tabs\t\t")
#View vector
vec |> stringr::str_view()
```

## Default trimming

By default the command removes all white spaces from both sides of strings.

```{r}
#Trim all white spaces from the start and end of strings
vec |> stringr::str_trim() |> stringr::str_view()
```

__Note:____`str_trim()` does not remove white spaces that are not at the start or end of a string.

```{r}
"Here is a space: . Here is a tab:\t. Here is a new line:\n. " |>
    stringr::str_trim() |>
    stringr::str_view()
```

## Side

The side to remove white spaces from can be chosen with `side=`.

```{r}
#Trim all white spaces from the start/left-side strings
vec |> stringr::str_trim(side = "left") |> stringr::str_view()
```

```{r}
#Trim all white spaces from the end/right-side strings
vec |> stringr::str_trim(side = "right") |> stringr::str_view()
```

```{r}
#Trim all white spaces from  bothsides strings
vec |> stringr::str_trim(side = "both") |> stringr::str_view()
```
